1106999899906670592.text: Efficiency is an optimal cost to fulfill a purpose. In the door example, a steel plate door is more secure, but not efficient if a deadbolt will suffice. Similarly, if you could use half the steel and a camera system to achieve equal security for less cost, it’s more efficient.

- don’t read the news
- don’t discuss politics 
- don’t opine without lots of personal investigation
- don’t read a book past 5-10% if not clearly unique

Say no to noise

1125092903309717509.text: 4/ Niche mainchains with their own unique properties will arise naturally from competition, and the market will decide if the benefits outweight the initial counterparty validation risk.

1125092902118526977.text: 3/ Atomicity of value transfers will initially be the first major macro-level, intra-crypto-network application, but will incur high fail-over probability, especially before chains establish reputation and evidence of long-term survivability.

1125092900956704769.text: 2/ We will see multiple communication standards + main chains, with select few owning majority marketshare, as well as many specialized smaller entities.

1125092899379662848.text: 1/ The global "crypto-fabric" will likely arise organically as a collection of main chains interoperated by dis-intermediated bridges, channels, pooled validator hubs, etc. Unlikely there will be a one-size-fits-all interop solution or comm. standard.

1115038754559803392.text: In typical database sharding, every shard is responsible for its own security guarantees. Any state transition operations applied to the shard are opaque to outsiders and unverifiable. This is perfectly fine because you assume shards are not arbitrarily malicious.

1115038752970162176.text: Intuitively, this is a very sensible design. In fact, this is seen in almost every single large scale network system. The problem is that, unlike crypto, other systems don’t have to worry about security dilution.https://twitter.com/dieguito/status/1114997339800862729 …

1089604609042272256.text: 3/ If the attacker is *at least as large* as the active set of miners over the past year, per Nakamoto protocol the shadow chain would become the valid chain, overwriting the rest of the network. The attacker would gather all block rewards over the past year.

1089604608341757952.text: 2/ Indeed, it is true that -- starting from zero -- overwriting 6 blocks is *computationally* more expensive than overwriting a whole year. However, an attacker can privately mine a chain for a whole year, and then display the chain to the world.

1089604607574196226.text: 1/ A common misconception that a friend of mine pointed out yesterday when he said "overwriting 6 blocks in bitcoin is more expensive than a full year of bitcoin". It's more subtle than that.

1046437932708614145.text: What about some other protocols? There exist protocols out there that do not even define a mining function, so for sure this paper does not apply. There are also protocols where mining is defined for multiple miners, using some threshold signatures.

1046437931450331138.text:
Conversely, systems that use PoS but that have instant finality (and therefore no forks), are necessarily not prone to the nothing at stake attack, double-spend, etc (under reasonable assumptions). 
 
 So protocols with instant finality do not really apply to this work.

1046437930343047169.text: If a PoS-variant of Bitcoin existed, then the longer the dependency on the longest chain, the more likely we are to run a nothing-at-stake attack on the system.

1046437929210597376.text: Anybody that prematurely committed during the partition will get wiped out, but that's a well understood risk. However, this robustness comes at a disadvantage.

1046437927973195776.text: If a network partition happens in Bitcoin, and two forks initiate for some period of time, no worries because at some point we will amend the partition and merge the forks.

1046437926882750464.text: The actual insight is in the trade-offs between recency and predictability, which isn't obvious. Bitcoin is very robust because of its reliance on longest-chain property that unrolls all the way back to genesis.

1046437925616070658.text: Ok, so that was some basic insight. I'll maybe write a full report on this at some point if I have the time. But, more importantly, what is the takeaway? The paper is neat, but most of the attacks are well known already.

1046437924324200448.text: …interesting case is if you don't have global predictability, and that the mining function acts as a random oracle ala-Bitcoin nonce. The attack doesn't theoretically change, but what changes is the probability distribution that the attack is successful.

1046437923166593026.text:
…threshold required by the merchant to deliver you the goods, or as the authors say it "can I create some minimum number of blocks faster than the rest of the users?" If a PoS protocol has D-global predictability and this is D is very high, don't use it. 
 
 The more…

1046437922000523265.text: If you have global predictability, you are able to predict which blocks will be mined by which coins in the future. To launch the attack, you simply need to find the first instance where coins under your controls will generate a sequence of blocks longer than some minimum…

1046437920868110336.text:
It is my opinion that the other attacks are different ways of thinking about the same core underlying fallacy of longest-chain protocols using PoS, so a lot of them are just very repetitive. 
 
 Let me give you intuition for the double-spend attack.

1046437919739850752.text: For the sake of brevity, I'm going to focus on only D-predictability, and specifically how you can launch a double-spend attack.

1046437918351351808.text: A protocol is D-recent if the latest block depends only on information from the last D blocks. If the protocol is 1-recent, then we can only make usage of the last block.

1046437917110005760.text:
The predictability could be only local, meaning that only you are able to predict the miner at B_{i+D}, or it could be global, meaning that every participant in the network can do the same. 
 The second property is recency.

1046437915478364160.text: In any case, we are interested in two properties that arise if the model fits you. The first one, predictability, says that a PoS protocol is D-predictable if at block B_i, information about the miner can be predicted D-blocks into the future.

1046437914027143169.text: If your protocol doesn't have these two functions, this paper already doesn't apply. Also, as you might have already guessed, if your protocol doesn't make usage of a "longest-chain" rule, it also doesn't apply.

1046437912655671296.text: First, the paper creates a formal model of a longest-chain PoS protocol. A PoS protocol, according to the authors, must define two special functions, mine and verify, which serve the purposes you might already guess.

1046437911275671552.text: Basic thread on the "Formal Barriers to Longest-Chain Proof-of-Stake Protocols" by @random_walker. I've already seen people incorrectly cite it, so I think this thread might be worthwhile.

1045387152203354113.text: Reminder: the number of confirmations necessary to be safe against a double-spend in Bitcoin increases asymptotically as the mining power of the adversary reaches 50%. At 50%, no solution is feasible.pic.twitter.com/597bxjT684

1041738433897684992.text: The DAG is just a way to structure your core data-structure. A blockchain is one variant. A DAG is another.

1041738432861622272.text: ... at least that I'm aware of. Delegated proof-of-stake is not a consensus protocol. Neither is the DAG. The former is just a name to basically describe a consensus protocol that uses classical-style voting mechanisms with delegated committees.

1041738431561453570.text: ... computational resources. In proof-of-stake, you stake. That's it. You put up actual money on the table to participate. In proof-of-storage, you may use storage to prove valid entry in the network, rather than PoW. Other types of Sybil mechanisms do not exist ...

1041738430273789954.text: We have a multitude of various different Sybil deterrence mechanisms. In proof-of-work, if you want to participate in the network you need to solve very heavy computational puzzles. It's not easy to overtake the network because you require very large ...

1041738429145473028.text: I say "partially" because the type of Sybil prevention mechanism that  you choose may affect how the consensus protocol is precisely designed. In any case, suppose for simplicity that you can just externalize the Sybil mechanism completely.

1041738427769741312.text: Second, we need to orthogonalize the consensus protocol from  the Sybil mechanism. The consensus protocol is the algorithm that every participating node in your system runs to achieve agreement. This is (partially) independent from the Sybil mechanism.

1041738426318561281.text: First, what is the Sybil problem? When you are trying to reach consensus, you need to rely on your peers. What if peers could be easily generated? Then I could just flood the system with fake identities and destroy consensus. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sybil_attack …

1041738425597087745.text: Sybil mechanisms are not consensus protocols. Thread.

1040011832289882117.text: Now this brings us to the usefulness of ZKs. It's limited! They prove statements, but cannot perform arbitrary computation, which brings us to FHE (fully homomorphic encryption). FHE implies the existence of ZK, but not vice versa.

1040011829718777856.text: If you are not able to and are lying to me, then you have only 1/2 change of guessing right everytime I toss my coin. So over N iterations, if you do indeed guess right every time, then the probability that you were lying to me is 2^-N.

1040011827130888202.text: To guess my coin flip, you will have to actually compute whether what I sent you was a QR or not. I won't go into the details, but the only thing that you need to know is the following: if you ACTUALLY do know if X is a QR or not, then you will be able to guess my coin flip.

1040011823725142016.text: I will generate a random R and toss a coin. If the coin is heads, I will send you R^2 mod Q, and if its tails I will send XR^2 mod Q. You have no idea which one I have chosen, and you will have to basically guess what the outcomes of my coin flip were.

1040011821128855552.text: You just have to show me the value R (1 < R < Q) that makes the statement true. What if you wanted to prove to me that X is NOT a quadratic residue (and of course, I don't want to go through all the possible R values to figure this out myself). We can construct an interactive ZKP

1040011818612269056.text: ZK proofs are good are proving information about X without revealing X. Let's provide a basic construction mathematically, using quadratic residues (this will be a basic primer). Call X a quadratic residue modulo Q if X = R^2 mod Q. Proving that X is a quad. residue is simple.

1030175225302986753.text: Conclusion of this thread: don't really believe a game theoretic analysis of a public blockchain system immediately. Question fundamental assumptions.https://twitter.com/kevinsekniqi/status/1030174737312428032 …

1030174741708120064.text: 5. ... but where "action X" is directly impacting the system in a negative way, then participants will choose to simply no longer participate, therefore minimizing utility.

1030174740764348416.text: 4. In blockchains, most game theoretic arguments I've seen are only valid by assuming that participation is somehow enforced, regardless of choices between participants. Often times, this is not the case. If someone concludes that "action X" maximizes utility ...

1030174739548065795.text: 3. A game theoretic analysis no longer holds, because the conditions of the system are presented only if the participants believe in these conditions. This is often seen in blockchain game analysis.

1030174738474258432.text: 2. In this universe, the system is enforceable: the prisoners have no choice but to participate in the game. In a non-enforceable prisoner's dilemma, the prisoners can simply chose to walk out and not participate.

1030174737312428032.text: 1. A game theoretic analysis of is valid only for enforceable systems. This is often mistakenly missed. Eg. in the prisoner's dilemma, prisoners are given the choice to defect or cooperate.
